title: Roman Emperor Caracalla is assassinated. He is succeeded by his Praetorian Guard prefect, Marcus Opellius Macrinus.
text: • 217 – Roman Emperor Caracalla is assassinated. He is succeeded by his Praetorian Guard prefect, Marcus Opellius Macrinus.

title: King Charibert II is assassinated at Blaye (Gironde), along with his infant son Chilperic.
text: • 632 – King Charibert II is assassinated at Blaye (Gironde), along with his infant son Chilperic.

title: The Battle of Dayr al
text: • 876 – The Battle of Dayr al-'Aqul saves Baghdad from the Saffarids.

title: The new Winchester Cathedral is dedicated by Walkelin.
text: • 1093 – The new Winchester Cathedral is dedicated by Walkelin.

title: Roger II of Sicily is excommunicated.
text: • 1139 – Roger II of Sicily is excommunicated.

title: Pope Eugene III takes refuge in the castle of Ptolemy II of Tusculum.
text: • 1149 – Pope Eugene III takes refuge in the castle of Ptolemy II of Tusculum.

title: Mongol
text: • 1232 – Mongol–Jin War: The Mongols begin their siege on Kaifeng, the capital of the Jin dynasty.

title: In Syria, sultan Baibars conquers the Krak des Chevaliers.
text: • 1271 – In Syria, sultan Baibars conquers the Krak des Chevaliers.

title: English colonial patents are granted for the establishment of the Monmouth Tract, for what would eventually become Monmouth County in northeastern New Jersey.
text: • 1665 – English colonial patents are granted for the establishment of the Monmouth Tract, for what would eventually become Monmouth County in northeastern New Jersey.

title: Shearith Israel, the first synagogue in New York City, is dedicated.
text: • 1730 – Shearith Israel, the first synagogue in New York City, is dedicated.

title: War of Jenkins' Ear: Three British ships capture the Spanish third
text: • 1740 – War of Jenkins' Ear: Three British ships capture the Spanish third-rate Princesa, taken into service as HMS Princess.

title: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Baltimore is promoted to an archdiocese, with the founding of the dioceses of New York, Philadelphia, Boston, and Bardstown (now Louisville) by Pope Pius VII.
text: • 1808 – The Roman Catholic Diocese of Baltimore is promoted to an archdiocese, with the founding of the dioceses of New York, Philadelphia, Boston, and Bardstown (now Louisville) by Pope Pius VII.

title: The Venus de Milo is discovered on the Aegean island of Milos.
text: • 1820 – The Venus de Milo is discovered on the Aegean island of Milos.

title: Black Hawk War: Around three
text: • 1832 – Black Hawk War: Around three-hundred United States 6th Infantry troops leave St. Louis, Missouri to fight the Sauk Native Americans.

title: American Civil War: Battle of Mansfield: Union forces are thwarted by the Confederate army at Mansfield, Louisiana.
text: • 1864 – American Civil War: Battle of Mansfield: Union forces are thwarted by the Confederate army at Mansfield, Louisiana.

title: Italy and Prussia ally against the Austrian Empire.
text: • 1866 – Italy and Prussia ally against the Austrian Empire.

title: William Ewart Gladstone introduces the first Irish Home Rule Bill into the British House of Commons.
text: • 1886 – William Ewart Gladstone introduces the first Irish Home Rule Bill into the British House of Commons.

title: In Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. the Supreme Court of the United States declares unapportioned income tax to be unconstitutional.
text: • 1895 – In Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. the Supreme Court of the United States declares unapportioned income tax to be unconstitutional.

title: The French Third Republic and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland sign the Entente cordiale.
text: • 1904 – The French Third Republic and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland sign the Entente cordiale.

title: Longacre Square in Midtown Manhattan is renamed Times Square after The New York Times.
text: • 1904 – Longacre Square in Midtown Manhattan is renamed Times Square after The New York Times.

title: Auguste Deter, the first person to be diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, dies.
text: • 1906 – Auguste Deter, the first person to be diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, dies.

title: Harvard University votes to establish the Harvard Business School.
text: • 1908 – Harvard University votes to establish the Harvard Business School.

title: Dutch physicist Heike Kamerlingh Onnes discovers superconductivity.
text: • 1911 – Dutch physicist Heike Kamerlingh Onnes discovers superconductivity.

title: The 17th Amendment to the United States Constitution, requiring direct election of Senators, becomes law.
text: • 1913 – The 17th Amendment to the United States Constitution, requiring direct election of Senators, becomes law.

title: In Corona, California, race car driver Bob Burman crashes, killing three (including himself), and badly injuring five spectators.
text: • 1916 – In Corona, California, race car driver Bob Burman crashes, killing three (including himself), and badly injuring five spectators.

title: World War I: Actors Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin sell war bonds on the streets of New York City's financial district.
text: • 1918 – World War I: Actors Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin sell war bonds on the streets of New York City's financial district.

title: Sharia courts are abolished in Turkey, as part of Atatürk's Reforms.
text: • 1924 – Sharia courts are abolished in Turkey, as part of Atatürk's Reforms.

title: Indian independence movement: At the Delhi Central Assembly, Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt throw handouts and bombs to court arrest.
text: • 1929 – Indian independence movement: At the Delhi Central Assembly, Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt throw handouts and bombs to court arrest.

title: The Works Progress Administration is formed when the Emergency Relief Appropriation Act of 1935 becomes law.
text: • 1935 – The Works Progress Administration is formed when the Emergency Relief Appropriation Act of 1935 becomes law.

title: World War II: Siege of Leningrad: Soviet forces open a much
text: • 1942 – World War II: Siege of Leningrad: Soviet forces open a much-needed railway link to Leningrad.

title: World War II: The Japanese take Bataan in the Philippines.
text: • 1942 – World War II: The Japanese take Bataan in the Philippines.

title: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an attempt to check inflation, freezes wages and prices, prohibits workers from changing jobs unless the war effort would be aided thereby, and bars rate increases by common carriers and public utilities.
text: • 1943 – U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an attempt to check inflation, freezes wages and prices, prohibits workers from changing jobs unless the war effort would be aided thereby, and bars rate increases by common carriers and public utilities.

title: Otto and Elise Hampel are executed in Berlin for their anti
text: • 1943 –Otto and Elise Hampel are executed in Berlin for their anti-Nazi activities.

title: World War II: After an air raid accidentally destroys a train carrying about 4,000 Nazi concentration camp internees in Prussian Hanover, the survivors are massacred by Nazis.
text: • 1945 – World War II: After an air raid accidentally destroys a train carrying about 4,000 Nazi concentration camp internees in Prussian Hanover, the survivors are massacred by Nazis.

title: Électricité de France, the world's largest utility company, is formed as a result of the nationalisation of a number of electricity producers, transporters and distributors.
text: • 1946 – Électricité de France, the world's largest utility company, is formed as a result of the nationalisation of a number of electricity producers, transporters and distributors.

title: India and Pakistan sign the Liaquat
text: • 1950 – India and Pakistan sign the Liaquat–Nehru Pact.

title: U.S. President Harry Truman calls for the seizure of all domestic steel mills in an attempt to prevent the 1952 steel strike.
text: • 1952 – U.S. President Harry Truman calls for the seizure of all domestic steel mills in an attempt to prevent the 1952 steel strike.

title: Mau Mau leader Jomo Kenyatta is convicted by British Kenya's rulers.
text: • 1953 – Mau Mau leader Jomo Kenyatta is convicted by British Kenya's rulers.

title: A Royal Canadian Air Force Canadair Harvard collides with a Trans
text: • 1954 – A Royal Canadian Air Force Canadair Harvard collides with a Trans-Canada Airlines Canadair North Star over Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, killing 37 people.

title: South African Airways Flight 201 A de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1 crashes into the sea during night killing 21 people.
text: • 1954 – South African Airways Flight 201 A de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1 crashes into the sea during night killing 21 people.

title: A team of computer manufacturers, users, and university people led by Grace Hopper meets to discuss the creation of a new programming language that would be called COBOL.
text: • 1959 – A team of computer manufacturers, users, and university people led by Grace Hopper meets to discuss the creation of a new programming language that would be called COBOL.

title: The Organization of American States drafts an agreement to create the Inter
text: • 1959 – The Organization of American States drafts an agreement to create the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: The Netherlands and West Germany sign an agreement to negotiate the return of German land annexed by the Dutch in return for 280 million German marks as Wiedergutmachung.
text: • 1960 – The Netherlands and West Germany sign an agreement to negotiate the return of German land annexed by the Dutch in return for 280 million German marks as Wiedergutmachung.

title: A large explosion on board the MV Dara in the Persian Gulf kills 238.
text: • 1961 – A large explosion on board the MV Dara in the Persian Gulf kills 238.

title: The Gemini 1 test flight is conducted.
text: • 1964 – The Gemini 1 test flight is conducted.

title: BOAC Flight 712 catches fire shortly after take off. As a result of her actions in the accident, Barbara Jane Harrison is awarded a posthumous George Cross, the only GC awarded to a woman in peacetime.
text: • 1968 – BOAC Flight 712 catches fire shortly after take off. As a result of her actions in the accident, Barbara Jane Harrison is awarded a posthumous George Cross, the only GC awarded to a woman in peacetime.

title: Bahr El
text: • 1970 – Bahr El-Baqar primary school bombing: Israeli bombers strike an Egyptian school. Forty-six children are killed.

title: At Atlanta
text: • 1974 – At Atlanta–Fulton County Stadium, Hank Aaron hits his 715th career home run to surpass Babe Ruth's 39-year-old record.

title: Frank Robinson manages the Cleveland Indians in his first game as major league baseball's first African American manager.
text: • 1975 – Frank Robinson manages the Cleveland Indians in his first game as major league baseball's first African American manager.

title: Los Angeles Dodgers executive Al Campanis resigns amid controversy over racially charged remarks he had made while on Nightline.
text: • 1987 – Los Angeles Dodgers executive Al Campanis resigns amid controversy over racially charged remarks he had made while on Nightline.

title: Retired tennis great Arthur Ashe announces that he has AIDS, acquired from blood transfusions during one of his two heart surgeries.
text: • 1992 – Retired tennis great Arthur Ashe announces that he has AIDS, acquired from blood transfusions during one of his two heart surgeries.

title: The Republic of Macedonia joins the United Nations.
text: • 1993 – The Republic of Macedonia joins the United Nations.

title: Haryana Gana Parishad, a political party in the Indian state of Haryana, merges with the Indian National Congress.
text: • 1999 – Haryana Gana Parishad, a political party in the Indian state of Haryana, merges with the Indian National Congress.

title: War in Darfur: The Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement is signed by the Sudanese government and two rebel groups.
text: • 2004 – War in Darfur: The Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement is signed by the Sudanese government and two rebel groups.

title: Shedden massacre: The bodies of eight men, all shot to death, are found in a field in Shedden, Elgin County, Ontario. The murders are soon linked to the Bandidos Motorcycle Club.
text: • 2006 – Shedden massacre: The bodies of eight men, all shot to death, are found in a field in Shedden, Elgin County, Ontario. The murders are soon linked to the Bandidos Motorcycle Club.

title: The construction of the world's first skyscraper to integrate wind turbines is completed in Bahrain.
text: • 2008 – The construction of the world's first skyscraper to integrate wind turbines is completed in Bahrain.

title: The Islamic State of Iraq enters the Syrian Civil War and begins by declaring a merger with the Al
text: • 2013 – The Islamic State of Iraq enters the Syrian Civil War and begins by declaring a merger with the Al-Nusra Front under the name Islamic State of Iraq and ash-Sham.
